<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_close_:
```c
static int lfs_file_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    int err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);
#else
    int err = 0;
#endif

    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist*)file);

    // clean up memory
    if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }

    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. In this fragment file->cache.buffer is being freed (lfs_free takes a void *), so the buffer must be a modifiable object and cannot reasonably be const. The surrounding check (if (!file->cfg->buffer)) indicates that an external buffer in cfg is not present, so the implementation frees its internal cache buffer. Rule 8.13 would only be violated if a pointer was declared non-const even though the pointed data is never modified; there is no evidence here of that. (A hypothetical violation would occur if file->cache.buffer were declared as a non-const pointer but the code never modified the pointee — or conversely if a const-qualified buffer were cast away to call lfs_free.)
